questions.question: Which statement is false?
choices: There is enough food currently being grown to feed all of the world's people.
Not getting enough to eat is often due to poverty.
About one in six world citizens does not get enough food to eat.
Political upheaval, corruption, and war rarely affect food being distributed to those who need it.

questions.question: Chronic malnutrition means
choices: not getting enough calories in your diet.
a diet lacking enough protein and key nutrients.
a diet lacking iron and carbohydrates.

questions.question: A long-term diet lacking trace amounts of iodine may result in
A severe shortage of food accompanied by long-term hunger of most of the population, many deaths, and social disruption is called
Ironically, those who are overnourished face similar health problems of those who are undernourished.
These foods provide almost 50% of daily calories consumed by people of the world.
Industrialized agriculture is also called high-input agriculture because
choices: many resources must be used to gain a high crop yield.
this type of farming requires large amounts of sunlight, time, animal work, animal wastes for fertilizers, etc.- that is, many natural materials.
it takes much human work to gain high crop yields.

questions.question: Which type of farming is most used by the poor tropical farmer?
Soil "layers" of distinctive composition are called soil
The green revolution was made possible by large inputs of water, fertilizers, and pesticides, increasing the number of crops grown per year per plot of land, and
choices: increasing the amount of land used for farming.

questions.question: For thousands of years we have been modifying plants by crossbreeding and hybridization. These processes have yielded the domesticated crop plants we eat today. Aside from the 10-15 years it takes to develop a new variety of tomato or corn, what disadvantage is there to new varieties produced by this method?
choices: Pests and diseases reduce the plants' yield/resistance/vigor within 5-10 years.
People soon get tired of the taste.

questions.question: Meat animals (primarily cattle, pigs, and chickens)
choices: are mostly in feed lots, with feed grains supplied by the farmer.
mostly live in large buildings, fed grains, living out their lives indoors.
are mostly grazed under open sky, eating plants available to them.
are either grazed in open fields and rangelands (about 50%) or live in confined pens/cages/buildings (about %).

questions.question: The fastest growing area of food production currently is
The "blue revolution" refers to
choices: changing the world diet from meat to fish.

questions.question: Topsoil erosion leads to
Repeated annual application of irrigated water in dry climates leads to a buildup of salts in upper soil layers in a process called
Genetically modified (GM) foods
choices: have been acclaimed universally as a remarkable and needed agricultural breakthrough.
are engineered so that there are no environmental problems.

questions.question: The kind of chemical used to kill pest plants is called a/an
An old method of farming has been found to be helpful in keeping pest populations low. This practice is
choices: applying animal manure to crop fields.
keeping seed from one season to be planted the next season.

questions.question: In order to help improve food production, governments sometimes ________ as a way of helping farmers.
choices: provide subsidies, including tax breaks, to keep farmers in business
take a "hands off" approach, letting the marketplace decide prices

questions.question: Terracing, contour planting, strip planting, and wind breaks all have this in common: they are mainly used to
choices: allow small farmers to stay in business.

questions.question: In terms of being healthy and living longer, studies indicate the poorest diet
choices: is high in vegetables and fruits, and low in meats.
includes moderate amounts of meat, cheese, and seafood.
has a very high meat and starch component.
